name: Stakeholder Interests
what: This subtopic covers the specific interests and issues that each type of stakeholder has in relation to a business. Different stakeholders have different priorities, ranging from profitability and dividends to job satisfaction and environmental sustainability.
why: Understanding what each stakeholder group wants from a business allows managers to make informed decisions that balance competing demands. Ignoring stakeholder interests can lead to conflict, reduced performance, and reputational damage.

items.title: I can describe the interests of owners and shareholders
items.what: Owners aim for profitability, ethical operations, and socially responsible behaviour. Shareholders specifically want to receive dividends (dividend yield) and see their share value increase (capital appreciation).
items.why: Owners and shareholders provide the financial foundation of a business, and understanding their interests is key to maintaining investment and business viability.
items.example: Shareholders in a publicly listed company like Coles expect to receive annual dividends from profits and want the share price to grow over time, giving them a return on their investment.

items.title: I can describe the interests of managers and employees
items.what: Managers seek involvement in goal setting, fair remuneration, career development, and job satisfaction. Employees want fair wages, a non-discriminatory workplace, career advancement, job security, and to work for an ethical business.
items.why: These internal stakeholders drive the day-to-day operations of the business. Their satisfaction and motivation directly affect productivity, quality of service, and staff turnover.
items.example: An employee at Bunnings has an interest in receiving a fair wage, feeling secure in their long-term employment, and working in a respectful, diverse environment that values their contribution.

items.title: I can describe the interests of customers
items.what: Customers want quality goods and services, high levels of customer service (both pre-sale and post-sale), and assurance that the business acts ethically and responsibly. Some customers also value supporting Australian-made or Australian-owned businesses.
items.why: Customers are the primary source of revenue for a business. Meeting their interests builds loyalty, repeat business, and a positive reputation.
items.example: A customer purchasing from Signet (a packaging supplier) is interested in receiving environmentally friendly, sustainably sourced packaging products that are delivered reliably and at a fair price.

items.title: I can describe the interests of suppliers and competitors
items.what: Suppliers want their customers to be profitable so they get paid, want prompt payment, and seek long-term preferred supplier relationships. Competitors aim to gain competitive edge, greater market share, and to differentiate their products or services.
items.why: Suppliers and competitors are key operating environment stakeholders. Their actions influence costs, product availability, and market dynamics.
items.example: A produce supplier to Woolworths wants guaranteed ongoing orders, fair pricing, and prompt payment within agreed terms, while a competitor like Coles wants to attract more customers away from Woolworths through better pricing or service.

items.title: I can describe the interests of the community and society
items.what: The community benefits from employment opportunities and wants businesses to participate in their local area, act as responsible corporate citizens, operate ethically, and be environmentally sustainable.
items.why: Community expectations shape a business's social licence to operate. Businesses that ignore community interests risk public backlash, regulatory action, and loss of customer trust.
items.example: A community near a manufacturing plant expects the business to minimise pollution, create local jobs, and contribute to community events or causes, such as sponsoring a local sports club.
